title: 109_s3559
content: The Act may be cited as the "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005". It addresses fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" amends Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code by adding a section on fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits. It prohibits falsifying, concealing, or making false statements in matters involving benefits authorized in connection with a major disaster or emergency declaration. The Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005 imposes fines and imprisonment for fraud related to disaster declarations or emergency declarations under the Disaster Relief Act of 1974. The fraud must involve interstate or foreign commerce or the transportation of benefits through the mail. The Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005 imposes penalties for fraud related to disaster or emergency declarations under the Disaster Relief Act of 1974. It includes fines and imprisonment for fraud involving the transportation of benefits through the mail or any record, voucher, payment, money, or thing of value provided by the government. The Act increases criminal penalties for wire, radio, and television fraud during a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. It also increases penalties for engaging in mail fraud during the same circumstances. SEC. 4 amends Section 1341 of title 18, United States Code to increase criminal penalties for engaging in mail fraud during a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. SEC. 5 directs the Sentencing Commission. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to increase penalties for fraud or theft offenses related to major disaster or emergency declarations. They must also submit an explanation of their actions to Congress and provide policy recommendations for combating these offenses. The Sentencing Commission must ensure that sentencing guidelines reflect the seriousness of offenses related to major disasters or emergencies and make necessary changes to meet the purposes. The Sentencing Commission must enhance guidelines to reflect the seriousness of offenses related to disasters or emergencies, make conforming changes, and ensure guidelines meet sentencing purposes. The Commission has emergency authority to promulgate guidelines or amendments within 30 days of enactment, following specified procedures.
